document.docAuthor: Rojas-Runjaic, Fernando J. M. & Koch, Claudia & Castroviejo-Fisher, Santiago & Prudente, Ana L. C.
document.docTitle: A new dwarf gecko of the genus Pseudogonatodes (Squamata: Sphaerodactylidae) from the eastern slope of the Andean Cordillera de Mérida in northern South America

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new dwarf gecko of the genus Pseudogonatodes (Squamata: Sphaerodactylidae) from the eastern slope of the Andean Cordillera de Mérida in northern South America

emphasis.docTitle:
A new dwarf gecko of the genus
Pseudogonatodes
( Squamata : Sphaerodactylidae ) from the eastern slope of the Andean Cordillera de Mérida in northern South America

subSection.paragraph: FERNANDO J. M. ROJAS-RUNJAIC 1,2,5, *, CLAUDIA KOCH 3,6 , SANTIAGO CASTROVIEJO-FISHER 4,7 & ANA L. C. PRUDENTE 1,8

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Laboratório de Herpetologia, Coordenação de Zoologia, Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi, Belém, Pará, Brazil
Museo de Historia Natural La Salle, Fundación La Salle de Ciencias Naturales, Caracas, Distrito Capital , Venezuela
Leibniz Institute for the Analysis of Biodiversity Change, Museum Koenig, Bonn, Germany
Departamento de Zoología, Universidad de Sevilla, Sevilla, Spain

subSection.paragraph: *Corresponding author: � rojas_runjaic@yahoo.com

Pseudogonatodes
is a poorly known genus of small bodied, diurnal, ground-dwelling geckos widely distributed in northern South America. No additional species have been described in over two decades. Herein we describe a new species from the eastern slope of the Cordillera de Mérida in the Venezuelan Andes. The new species is readily diagnosable morphologically from the other seven recognized species of
Pseudogonatodes
by having a single postnasal scale—a putative autapomorphy. Furthermore, it is characterized by a unique combination of phenotypic characters that includes granular dorsal scales, three large postrostrals, five to six loreals, mental U-shaped, four to six postmentals, 26–29 ventrals between anterior levels of fore- and hind limbs, third lamella under fourth toe not distinctly enlarged, and subcaudal pattern 1’1”. In addition to characterizing the external morphology, we present a description of the skull, based on 3D digital models reconstructed from high resolution computed microtomography scans. The discovery of this new species highlights the still underestimated diversity of this group of Neotropical dwarf geckos and underscores the need for further studies on its systematics and taxonomy.

Key words: Gekkota , lizard , Neotropics ,
new species
, osteology , reptile ,
Venezuela

Pseudogonatodes
es un género de geckos de tamaño corporal pequeño, diurnos y terrestres, ampliamente distribuidos en el norte de Sudamérica. Ninguna especie nueva había sido descubierta en más de dos décadas. En este estudio describimos una nueva especie de la vertiente oriental de la Cordillera de Mérida en los Andes de Venezuela . La nueva especie es fácilmente diagnosticada de las otras siete especies de
Pseudogonatodes
reconocidas, por presentar una sola escama postnasal—un carácter aparentemente autapomórfico. Adicionalmente, se caracteriza por una combinación única de caracteres fenotípicos que incluye escamas dorsales granulares, tres grandes postrostrales, cinco a seis loreales, mentoniana en forma de U, cuatro a seis postmentonianas, 26–29 ventrales entre los niveles anteriores de los miembros anteriores y posteriores, tercera lamela subdigital del cuarto dedo de la pata no agrandada y patrón subcaudal 1’1”. Además de la caracterización morfológica externa, presentamos una descripción del cráneo basada en modelos virtuales 3D reconstruidos a partir de microtomografías computarizadas de alta resolución. El descubrimiento de esta nueva especie deja en evidencia la subestimación de la diversidad de este grupo de geckos enanos neotropicales y resalta la necesidad de estudios adicionales sobre su sistemática y taxonomía.

Pseudogonatodes Ruthven, 1915
is a Neotropical sphaerodactylid genus widely distributed in northern South America, including Brazil , Colombia , Ecuador , the Guianas, Peru , and Venezuela (
Uetz et al . 2022
), with representatives in the Amazon basin, the Andes, the Guiana Shield, and the Coastal Range ( Fig. 1 ). This group of diurnal and cryptic colored dwarf geckos inhabits the leaf litter on the forest floor and is phenotypically characterized by having round pupils; dorsal scales small, granular and juxtaposed [the only exception being
P. barbouri ( Noble, 1921 )
, which has large, flat and imbricate dorsal scales]; ventral scales large, flat, smooth and imbricate; by lacking scutcheon scales and femoral pores; having short, slender, cylindrical, and clawed digits with transversely enlarged subdigital lamellae; claws enclosed in a compressed ungual sheath composed of five symmetric scales ( Ruthven 1915 ; Avila-Pires 1995 ); and by having only four phalanges in toe IV (
Gamble et al . 2011a
).

Within
Pseudogonatodes
, three phenetic groups have been defined, based on subdigital and dorsal scale characteristics ( Huey & Dixon 1970 ). The first group is defined by having an expanded third lamella on the fourth toe, low fourth toe lamellae count, and granular dorsal scales; this is composed of two species:
P. guianensis Parker, 1935
and
P. lunulatus ( Roux, 1927 )
. The second group only differs from the first one by having large flat and imbricate dorsal scales and is only represented by
P. barbouri
. The third group is characterized by the absence of an expanded third lamella on the fourth toe, a high fourth toe lamellae count, and by having granular dorsal scales; this last group includes
P. furvus Ruthven, 1915
,
P. gasconi Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed, 2000
,
P. manessi Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed, 2000
, and
P. peruvianus Huey & Dixon, 1970
.

Despite the wide distribution of
Pseudogonatodes
in northern South America and its occurrence in four different bioregions, only the seven species listed above are currently recognized.An eighth species (
P. amazonicus Vanzolini, 1967
) from western Amazonia, is currently considered as a junior synonym of
P. guianensis
( Hoogmoed 1973 ; Avila-Pires 1995 ) but it awaits a modern taxonomic revision. In addition, Mechler (1968) reported and discussed a putative new species from Cundinamarca department in Colombia , but did not formally describe it. Molecular evidence on the occurrence of deeply divergent lineages within
Pseudogonatodes guianensis
published by
Gamble et al . (2011b)
as well as some studies in progress (Rojas-Runjaic, pers. obs.) preliminarily indicate that the low number of
Pseudogonatodes species
currently known is likely a consequence of our lack of knowledge about the systematics and diversity of the genus and not of a truly depauperate species richness within this group of geckos.

The small body size, cryptic coloration, and secretive habits of all
Pseudogonatodes species
make them difficult to find in their habitat and, consequently, they are underrepresented in biological collections ( Mechler 1968 ). Probably for the same reason, most descriptions and redescriptions of these dwarf geckos were based on only a few specimens, or even on just a single specimen ( e.g. ,
P. furvus
and
P. gasconi
; Ruthven 1915 ; Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed 2000 ) and our current knowledge about the morphological variation within the genus is still very limited (
Montes-Correa et al . 2021
). Furthermore, the scarcity of fresh tissue samples from museum specimens available for genetic studies has hindered the inference of a comprehensive phylogenetic hypothesis and thus our knowledge of the evolutionary relationships of the
Pseudogonatodes species
, their species boundaries, and the potential discovery of morphologically cryptic species. Due to the aforementioned reasons,
Pseudogonatodes
is currently considered one of the least known genera of Neotropical geckos ( Mechler 1968 ;
Montes-Correa et al . 2021
). Minimizing the Linnean shortfall within
Pseudogonatodes
in our current scenario of climate change and accelerated biodiversity loss is then an urgent task.

Two herpetological surveys to the eastern slope of the Venezuelan Andes in 2015 and 2016, resulted in the collection of a small series of specimens of
Pseudogonatodes
. The study of their external morphology revealed that these Andean specimens belong to a new species objectively diagnosable by morphology from all other species currently recognized. In this study we morphologically describe and name the new species of
Pseudogonatodes
and provide an osteological description of its skull from 3D digital models.

Fieldwork .
A total of seven specimens were collected during two fieldtrips carried out on February 14–15, 2015 and October 17–20, 2016 , in a montane semideciduous forest area of the eastern versant of Cordillera de Mérida , Barinas state , Venezuela ( Fig. 1 ). At this location, diurnal and nocturnal visual surveys were performed for amphibians and reptiles, and collection sites were georeferenced using a GPS receiver Garmin 60CSX with datum WGS 84. The specimens were captured manually and transported in plastic bags to an improvised laboratory in the field, where they were photographed in life. After being photographed, the specimens were euthanized with an overdose of 2% lidocaine administrated by intraperitoneal injection, fixed in a 10% formalin solution, and preserved in 70% ethanol. Prior to fixation, a sample of muscle and/or liver tissue was dissected from some specimens. These samples were preserved in 99% ethanol for future molecular analyses.

Osteology. Detailed description and illustrations on the skull morphology of the genus
Pseudogonatodes
are already available (
Bauer et al . 2018
) based on the congener
P. barbouri
. Therefore, to avoid redundancy, we do not give a complete skull description of the new species in the results section, but instead concentrate on highlighting the differences from the skull of
P. barbouri
as well as previously uncommented aspects. We further present a comparative synopsis of the skull of our new species with that of
P. barbouri
and
P. furvus
(the type species of the genus). Information on the cranial morphology of
P. furvus
was taken from
Montes-Correa et al . (2021)
and from our own examination of the micro-CT images of MCZ R-29700, downloaded from the MorphoSource.org platform. High resolution computed microtomography scans from the specimens MHNLS 21643 (adult female, holotype ), MHNLS 22711 (adult female, paratype ), and MHNLS 22712 (adult male, paratype ) were conducted using a Bruker SkyScan 1173 X-ray microCT, at the Instituto do Petróleo e dos Recursos Naturais (IPR) of the Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Rio Grande do Sul , Brazil . Specimens were scanned in three or four parts, depending on their size. Scans were performed at a voltage of 43 kV and current of 114 μA, without the use of a filter; rotation steps of 0.25° were recorded over a 180° rotation and each acquisition was composed of 2,880 (for specimens scanned in three parts) or 3,840 projections (for specimens scanned in four parts), with 550 ms exposure time, three frames averaged per projection, and 8.15 ( MHNLS 21643) or 8.5 μm ( MHNLS 22711, 22712) voxel size. Reconstructions were obtained with NRecon 1.7.1.6 (Bruker microCT®) and visualized with CTvox 3.2.0 (Bruker microCT®). The scan of MHNLS 21643 was rendered in three dimensions and segmented to separate bones with the aid of Amira visualization software (FEI, Thermo Fisher Scientific). As these micro-CT scans do not render cartilage, non-mineralized skeletal structures were omitted from our osteological description. Osteological terminology follows
Bauer et al . (2018)
,
Daza et al . (2008)
, and Evans (2008) .

subSubSection.paragraph: Figs. 2–11 , 12C–E

MHNLS 21643 , adult female , from El Potrerito, ⁓

; Fig. 1 ), collected on
February 15, 2015
, by Daniel Quihua .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratypes :
Six specimens : an adult female ( MHNLS 22711 , field number DQ 83 ), an adult male ( MHNLS 22710 , field number DQ 82 ), and a juvenile ( MHNLS 22709 , field number DQ 81 ), from Sendero El Oso , Posada San Ramón , ⁓
6 km
N from Altamira de Cáceres , Bolívar municipality, Barinas state , Venezuela (8.878750°, - 70.497580°;
elevation 1,319 m asl
), collected on
October 17, 2016
, by Daniel Quihua , José Vieira & Dennys Mora ;
an adult male ( MHNLS 22712 , field number DQ 84) and a juvenile ( MHNLS 22713 , field number DQ 85), from the type locality, collected on
October 20, 2016
, by Daniel Quihua , José Vieira & Dennys Mora ; and a juvenile ( MHNLS 21644 , without field number) with the same data as the holotype
.

Definition.
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
is morphologically defined by the following combination of character states: (1) SVL : 27.5–30.2 mm in adult males, 31.3–33.6 mm in adult females; (2) posterodorsal margin of rostral W-shaped, with a median cleft; (3) three postrostrals; (4) median postrostral similar in size to lateral ones; (5) a single large postnasal scale; (6) five to six loreal scales; (7) 19–22 scales in a transverse row between the sutures of the 1 st and 2 nd supralabials on each side; (8) four to six supralabials; (9) four to five supraciliaries, the second being the largest; (10) four to five infralabials; (11) posterior margin of mental U-shaped, without posterior clefts; (12) four to six postmentals; (13) dorsal and lateral scales granular, juxtaposed; (14) 85–91 scales around midbody; (15) 20–22 ventrals in a transverse row at midbody; (16) 40–43 ventral scales along a midventral row, between throat and anterior border of cloaca; (17) 33–36 ventral scales along a midventral row, from anterior level of arms to anterior border of cloaca; (18) 26–29 ventral scales along a midventral row, between anterior levels of fore- and hind limbs; (19) 7–9 lamellae under fourth finger; (20) 8–10 lamellae under fourth toe; (21) third lamella under fourth toe not distinctly enlarged; (22) subcaudal pattern 1’1”.

Diagnosis. The new species differs from the other seven
Pseudogonatodes species
by the presence of a single large postnasal scale ( vs . two or three postnasal scales; see Table 1 ). In addition, it differs from
P. barbouri
by having juxtaposed granular dorsal scales ( vs . flat and imbricate), by lacking an expanded third lamella under fourth toe (TIV) ( vs . expanded), and by its larger body size, which reaches 33.6 mm SVL in adult females ( vs . up to 25.6 mm SVL;
Koch et al . 2018
). It is differentiated from
P. lunulatus
by lacking an expanded third lamella under TIV ( vs . expanded), by having heterogeneous scales on the sole of the foot ( vs . homogeneous), a large median postrostral, similar in size to the lateral ones ( vs . median postrostral smaller than lateral ones), 5–6 loreal scales in a straight line between postnasal and orbit ( vs . up to nine), 4–6 postmentals ( vs . 3–4), 8–10 infradigital lamellae under TIV ( vs . 6–7), and larger body size ( vs . up to 29 mm SVL;
Esqueda et al . 2016
). The new species further differs from
P. guianensis
by lacking an expanded third infradigital lamella under TIV ( vs . expanded), by having 33–36 ventral scales between anterior level of forelimb and cloaca ( vs . 36–47 VMR-b), 8–10 lamellae under TIV ( vs . 5–7), a medial row of slightly expanded subcaudal scales arranged in a 1’1” pattern ( vs . in some cases slightly expanded but without a pattern), and a larger body size in adult females ( vs . up to 30 mm ; Avila-Pires 1995 ).
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
is distinguished from
P. gasconi
by having a medial cleft on the posterior margin of the rostral ( vs . without cleft on posterior margin of rostral), granular dorsal scales ( vs . conical to flat conical dorsals), 26–29 ventral scales between anterior levels of fore- and hind limbs ( vs . 37 VMR-c), 5–6 loreal scales in a straight line between postnasal and orbit ( vs . 7 loreals), a medial row of slightly expanded subcaudal scales arranged in a 1’1” pattern ( vs . subcaudals unexpanded and unpatterned), and a larger body size, which ranges between 31.3–33.6 mm SVL in adult females ( vs . 24 mm SVL in the only known specimen, which is an adult female; Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed 2000 ). It is differentiated from
P. manessi
by having 5–6 loreal scales ( vs . 7–8), posterior margin of mental U-shaped, without posterior clefts ( vs . W-shaped, with or without two posterior clefts), 4–6 postmentals ( vs . 6–9), 26–29 ventral scales between anterior levels of forelimbs and hind limbs ( vs . 31–35 VMR-c), and 33–36 ventral scales until border of cloaca ( vs . 37–40 VMR-b), and a smaller body size ( vs . up to 38 mm SVL; Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed 2000 ). It is distinguished from
P. peruvianus
by having a large median postrostral, similar in size to the lateral ones ( vs . median postrostral about one-third the size of laterals), 85–91 scales around midbody ( vs . 79 SAM), 33–36 ventral scales between anterior level of forelimbs and border of cloaca ( vs . 42 VMR-b). Finally,
P. quihuai
differs from
P. furvus
by having 5–6 loreal scales ( vs . 7–10), posterior edge of mental without clefts ( vs . two median clefts), 4–6 postmentals ( vs . 2–4), 27–29 ventral scales between anterior levels of forelimbs and hind limbs ( vs . 34–39 VMR-c), and 33–36 ventral scales until border of cloaca ( vs . 44–67 VMR-b), 7–9 lamellae under 4 th finger ( vs . 11–13), 8–10 under TIV ( vs . 11–15), and a smaller body size, which does not exceed 33.6 mm ( vs . up to 45 mm SVL;
Montes-Correa et al . 2021
).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Synopsis of pholidotic characters of the eight species of
Pseudogonatodes
currently recognized and the specimen MIZA 15-185. See abbreviations in Materials and Methods section.? = Missing data.

Nearly straight to widely V-shaped, with a posterior median cleft
Roughly straight to concave, posterior clefts 1–3 or absent
V-shaped, with a posterior median cleft
W-shaped, with two posterior median clefts
V-shaped, with a short posterior medial cleft
W-shaped, with two or without posterior clefts
midventral row slightly to heavily enlarged, 1’1”

Koch et al . (2018)
; MontesCorrea et al . (2021); this study

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2. Holotype of
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
sp. nov.
(adult female, MHNLS 21643) in preservative. Dorsal (A) and ventral (B) views of the body. Scale bar represents 10 mm. Photos: F.J.M. Rojas-Runjaic.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description of the holotype .
Adult female in good state of preservation ( Fig. 2 ); SVL = 33.6 mm . Head coneshaped, HL = 6.8 mm (0.2 times SVL), slightly longer than wide (HL/HW = 1.3), depressed (HD/HW = 0.7), and as wide as the neck ( Fig. 2 ). Snout 2.6 mm long (0.4 times HL), subacuminate in dorsal view, rounded in profile, gently sloping toward top of head ( Fig. 3A–C ). Neck cylindrical, slightly narrower than body ( Fig. 2 ). Body wider than high, slightly depressed; axilla-groin distance 15.3 mm . Limbs short (forelimb 0.27 times SVL; hind limbs 0.33 times SVL), robust; digits clawed, well developed, five on hands and feet ( Fig. 4A–B ). Tail complete (not regenerated; Fig. 2 ), almost as long as the body (TL = 29.4 mm ; 0.9 times SVL), stout, tapering toward tip, round in cross section.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 3. Holotype of Pseudogonatodes quihuai sp. nov. (adult female, MHNLS 21643) in preservative. Dorsal (A), right lateral (B), left lateral (C), and ventral (D) views of the head. Scale bars represent 1 mm. Photos: F.J.M. Rojas-Runjaic.

subSubSection.paragraph: Rostral large, well visible from above ( Fig. 3A ); lateral borders vertical, almost straight, posterolaterally in contact with 1 st supralabial and anterior border of nostril of each side ( Fig. 3B–C ); posterodorsal margin of rostral W-shaped, with the medial concavity forming an angle of ~ 90º; a median cleft extending forward from posterior margin to near midpoint of the scale; rostral posteriorly in contact with three large postrostrals.All three postrostrals distinctly larger than adjacent scales on snout ( Fig. 3A ). Medial postrostral pentagonal, slightly wider than long, barely smaller than lateral ones; lateral postrostrals nearly rectangular, about twice as wide as long, posterolaterally in contact with postnasal. Nostril located at the anterior portion of nasal scale, bordered by lateral postrostral, rostral, and 1 st supralabial. A single large postnasal, nearly rounded, distinctly larger than adjacent loreal scales ( Fig. 3B–C ). Scales on dorsum of snout and loreal region juxtaposed, smooth; polygonal (nearly rounded) and flat on the anteriormost rows, gradually changing into smaller granules toward top of head ( Fig. 3A ). Nineteen scales on a transverse row on snout, between suture of 1 st and 2 nd supralabials of each side. Loreal scales 5/ 6 in row between postnasal and orbit. Scales on supraocular region granular, similar in size to adjacent scales on top of head. Four large, flattened scales aligned on anterior and upper margin of eye forming a supraciliary flap; second one the largest. Supralabials 5/5; 4 th supralabial (right side) and suture between 4 th and 5 th supralabial (left side) below center of eye. Scales on temporal region similar to those on top of head. Ear-opening small (less than half of eye diameter), roughly elliptical; 19/21 temporal scales in the shortest straight line between eye and ear-opening.

Scales on upper and anterior surfaces of forelimbs, and on anterior and ventral surfaces of hind limbs large, flat, smooth, imbricate; scales elsewhere on limbs small, granular, conical, juxtaposed to sub-imbricate. Scales on palms and soles heterogeneous in size, flat, polygonal, imbricate ( Fig. 4A–B ). Lamellae under first (I) through fifth (V) finger (right/left): I: 4/5; II: 7/7; III: 9(1 st divided)/8; IV: 8(1 st divided)/8(1 st divided); V: 6(1 st divided)/6. Lamellae under first (I) through fifth (V) toe (right/left): I: 5(1 st –3 rd divided)/5; II: 8(1 st –2 nd divided)/7; III: 8(1 st divided)/8(1 st divided); IV: 8(1 st divided)/9(1 st –2 nd divided); V: 8/8(1 st –3 rd divided). Third lamellae under fourth toe not distinctly enlarged ( Fig. 4B ). Basal lamellae of fingers and toes larger than distal ones. Claws enclosed in ungual sheaths composed of five enlarged scales.

Color in life and preservative. In life, dorsal and lateral surfaces of head, dorsum, flanks, and limbs dark brown, with some scattered whitish dots, mainly on flanks; background color of dorsal and lateral surfaces of tail also dark brown, but darker than head and trunk. Dorsal surface of head with a lighter, poorly defined occipital band posteriorly bordered by a thin blackish brown transverse line; supralabials and infralabials mottled blackish brown, with pale vertical stripes on lateral borders of such scales; a pale diagonal postrictal band, finely bordered with blackish brown, extending posteroventrally from angle of jaws to throat, where it continues backwards flanking the throat. A pair of thin, ill-defined, pale dorsolateral stripes extending backwards from postocular corners to distal third of tail, where they become inconspicuous; both dorsolateral stripes finely bordered with blackish brown from posterior third of dorsum to base of tail; from base of tail and to its distal third, pale dorsolateral stripes become broader and slightly sinuous. Chin and throat dirty white, laterally delimited by a blackish line. Chest, belly, ventral surfaces of thighs and tail brown, slightly lighter than flanks and dorsum; all the enlarged scales on these ventral regions are pale centrally and brown on margins. Iris bronze.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 4. Holotype of Pseudogonatodes quihuai sp. nov. (adult female, MHNLS 21643) in preservative. Ventral surfaces of the left hand (A) left foot (B), and tail (C). Scale bars represent 1 mm. Photos: F.J.M. Rojas-Runjaic.

subSubSection.paragraph: In preservative (after eight years), dark brown background color has become pale brown; blackish line posteriorly bordering the pale occipital band and those blackish lines flanking pale diagonal postrictal band, more conspicuous. Pale occipital band and pale dorsolateral stripes somewhat diffuse, less conspicuous. Whitish dots scattered on dorsum and flanks have faded, almost imperceptible. Iris pale gray.

Cranial osteology. The skull of
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
( Figs. 5–11 ) closely resembles that of
P. barbouri (
Bauer et al . 2018
)
in many aspects. Therefore, we only highlight those character states that differ from
P. barbouri
. Unless otherwise indicated, this osteological description applies to all three specimens examined. A comparative synopsis of osteological character states among
P. quihuai
,
P. barbouri
, and
P. furvus
is presented in Table 2 .

The premaxilla contacts the nasals and maxillae in all three specimens and the septomaxilla (internally) only in MHNLS 21643. The premaxilla bears 11 (n = 3) tooth loci on the ventral portion and there are 3‒4 rows of replacement tooth buds ( Fig. 8A ). The ascending nasal process extends beyond the anterior half of the median suture of the nasal bones ( Figs. 5A , 6A , 7A , 11A, D, F, I ). The palatal process does not contact the vomer in all three specimens . The maxillae do not contact the ectopterygoid medially in MHNLS 21643 whereas the two bones are in contact in MHNLS 22711 and MHNLS 22712. The maxilla bears 22‒24 (23.33 ± 0.82; n = 6) tooth loci ( Fig. 8A ). Slightly below the facial process, the maxilla bears a series of 2‒5 (3.17 ± 0.98; n = 6) foramina ( Figs. 5B , 11B, G ). The nasals are in firm medial contact along their entire length and anteromedially both nasals together form a channel into which the ascending process of the premaxilla fits, framing it ventrally and laterally ( Figs. 5A , 9A ). Posteriorly, the nasals greatly overlap the anterior part of the frontal ( Fig. 9 ). Viewed from internally, the posterolateral margin of each nasal contacts the medial margin of the prefrontal ( Fig. 8C ). The anteromedial ventral surface of each nasal has a broad contact zone with the anteromedial dorsal surface of the septomaxilla. Viewed from internally, the medial margin of the prefrontal contacts the posterolateral margin of each nasal ( Fig. 8C ). The lacrimal foramen is oval shaped rather than triangular.

The frontal bone is only partly fused or even paired, and the suture or at least a medial longitudinal indentation is visible dorsally and ventrally along the entire structure, being more pronounced ventrally and dorsally on the posterior third ( Figs. 9 , 11 ). Anterolaterally, the frontal bone is in broad contact with the posterodorsal part of the facial process of the maxilla ( Figs. 5A , 11A, F ). This aspect is not mentioned in
Bauer et al . (2018)
, but is also clearly visible in the figures of
Pseudogonatodes barbouri
. Anteriorly, the paired septomaxillae diverge, while in the posterior half they are about parallel to each other and only slightly separated without touching each other medially ( Figs. 7B , 8B ). The main body has a concave dorsal surface. The septomaxilla overlays the vomer dorsally and touches it with its posteromedial margin or remains slightly separated from it. In addition to the maxilla and vomer, the septomaxilla also contacts the nasal anteromedially and in MHNLS 21643 it even has a small contact point with the premaxilla anteriorly. The vomers are longer than wide, and become slightly broader posteriorly ( Fig. 5C ). They are paired but in firm contact in MHNLS 21643 ( Fig. 5C ) and MHNLS 22712 ( Fig. 11H ), but seem to be partially fused in the posterior region in MHNLS 22711 ( Fig. 11D ). The vomer does not contact the premaxilla anteriorly and whether it contacts the palatine posteriorly depends on the volume rendering threshold; however, if so, it is very marginal ( Fig. 7C ). A defined area for the vomerine process of the palatine is lacking. The palatines are partially very thin and broadly separated from another ( Figs. 7C , 11C, H ). The pterygoid does not contact the parabasisphenoid medially ( Figs. 7B , 8A , 11C, H ), as should be the case in
P. barbouri
according to its osteological description (
Bauer et al . 2018
); however, this appears to be an error in the description as the two bones appear clearly separated in
Bauer et al . (2018
: fig. 1C). The anterior process of each ectopterygoid is broader and slightly shorter than the posterior process ( Fig. 8B ). The posterior end of the maxilla extends beyond the vertex of the ectopterygoid in ventral view. The vertex region of the ectopterygoid laterally contacts the jugal ( Fig. 8A ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9. Micro-CT images of the holotype of
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
sp. nov.
(MHNLS 21643): frontal ( f ) and nasals ( n ) in dorsal (A) and ventral (B) views, and frontal alone in dorsal (C) and ventral (D) views.

subSubSection.paragraph:
As in
Pseudogonatodes barbouri (
Bauer et al . 2018
)
in MHNLS 21643 ( Figs. 5 , 6B , 7B , 8A ) and in MHNLS 22711 ( Fig. 11A‒C, E ) the parabasisphenoid, basioccipital, supraoccipital, prootic, and otooccipital are fused to form the braincase, although traces of a suture between the parabasisphenoid and basioccipital are visible in MHNLS 22711. In MHNLS 22712 ( Fig. 11F‒H, J ), the bones of the braincase are in close contact but not fused, and all sutures are visible. Dorsomedially the braincase contacts the posteriormedial part of the parietals in MHNLS 21643 ( Fig. 6B ), but not in MHNLS 22711 ( Fig. 11E ) and MHNLS 22712 ( Fig. 11J ). The two trabeculae between the basipterygoid processes are distinctly larger and more pronounced ( Figs. 7B , 11C, H ) than in
P. barbouri
.

Variation in
type series.
Morphological variation in external phenotypic characters, related to sexual dimorphism, is only evident in the SVL , with females being slightly larger than males ( 31.3–33.6 mm vs . 27.5–30.2 mm ). Regarding morphometry, there is very little variation in the observed body proportions of the
type series. The head is little longer ( HL / SVL = 0.3) in the juvenile MHNLS 21644 ( 0.2 in all the others), whereas it is slender in the subadult MHNLS 22709 ( HL /HW = 1.4 vs . 1.3 in the others). The head is always depressed but the HD/HW ratio is between 0.6–0.7. Finally, the snout is slightly shorter in the adult male MHNLS 22712 ( SL /HL = 0.3 vs . 0.4 in the others). All measurements of the
type series are listed in Appendix 2.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 11. Micro-CT images of the skulls of two paratypes of
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
sp. nov.
(MHNLS 22711: A‒E; MHNLS 22712: F‒J) in dorsal (A, F), lateral (B, G), ventral (C, H), anterior (D, I), and posterior (E, J) views.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Phenotypic variation is larger in scale counts (Appendix 3) and in the shape and proportions of some head scales; although the concavity of the dorsal-posterior margin of the rostral typically forms an angle of ⁓ 90°, it is> 90° in the specimen MHNLS 22709 . The median postrostral scale can be barely smaller ( MHNLS 21643 , 22709 , and 21644), equal ( MHNLS 22710–11 , 22713 ) or barely larger ( MHNLS 22712 ) than lateral postrostrals. The loreals range between 5–6 and vary in number even between opposite sides of the same individual in four of the seven specimens of the type series. The number of supraciliaries varies between 4 and 5; however, the 2 nd is always the largest. The number of scales of the snout in a transverse line between 1 st and 2 nd supralabials ranges from 19 to 22. The number of both supralabials and infralabials varies from 4 to 5; however, the specimen MHNLS 22710 has six supralabials on the right side. The number of postmentals varies between 4–6, with one or two scales in the middle of the row. The number of lamellae under the fingers and toes varies as follow: FI: 4–5, FII: 7–8, FIII : 8–9, FIV: 7–8, FV: 6–7; TI : 5–6, TII: 7–8, TIII : 8–10, TIV : 8–10, TV : 7–10. The distal subdigital lamellae of the fingers are sometimes divided sagittally, and those of toes are frequently divided. The 1 st subdigital lamella (counted from the tip to the base) is divided in 24 of 70 fingers (34%) and in 58 of 70 toes (83%); the 2 nd lamella is divided in 4 of 70 fingers (6%) and in 23 of 70 toes (33%); the 3 rd lamella is only divided in 5 of 70 toes (7%). The number of scales around midbody is 85–91 and there are 20–22 enlarged ventral scales in a transverse line at midbody. The number of enlarged ventral scales from throat to cloaca is 40–43; and 33–36 from the anterior border of forearms to cloaca, while there are 26–29 ventrals between anterior borders of fore- and hind limbs
.

The color pattern also exhibits some variation in the type series ( Fig. 12C–E ). The light occipital band may be ill-defined ( MHNLS 21643 , 22710 , and 22711), evident ( MHNLS 22713 ), or very well defined ( MHNLS 21644 , 22709 , and 22712); regarding color, this light band may be almost immaculate white ( MHNLS 22712 ), dirty white ( MHNLS 21644 , 22709 , 22713 ), light grayish brown ( MHNLS 22710–11 ), or light brown ( MHNLS 21643 ). The light occipital band also varies in form, being medially divided ( MHNLS 22709 ), medially constricted at its anterior margin ( MHNLS 22710 , 22712–13 ), or roughly uniform in its width ( MHNLS 21346 , 22711 ). The blackish-brown transverse line juxtaposed posteriorly to the pale occipital band, is wider and very conspicuous in MHNLS 22712–13 . The pale dorsolateral stripes are absent on neck and dorsum in MHNLS 22711 , and present in the remaining specimens of the type series. There are a series of small, thin, and very-spaced blackish dashes flanking pale dorsolateral stripes from neck to thighs level, in the specimens MHNLS 22709–10 , 22712–13 , which are absent in MHNLS 21643 and 22711. Finally, the juveniles MHNLS 21644 and 22713 are more densely spotted with white on the dorsum and flanks of the body. The ventral surface is quite similar in color pattern in the type series, but immature specimens ( MHNLS 21644 , 22709 , 22713 ) exhibit a thin pale stripe running longitudinally along the posteroventral surface of the thighs.

Distribution, habitat, and natural history.
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
is only known from two localities along the eastern slope of the Cordillera de Mérida in the Venezuelan Andes ( Figs. 1 , 12A ). Both localities are in the state of Barinas : El Potrerito ⁓ 2.2 km NW from Altamira de Cáceres ( type locality); and Sendero El Oso, Posada San Ramón, ⁓ 6 km N from Altamira de Cáceres (the northernmost and highest known locality). The known altitudinal range of
P. quihuai
(
1,120 –1,319 m
asl) is occupied by montane semideciduous forests ( Fig. 12A–B ), which is mainly characterized by the loss of foliage of most of its tree species during one to three months, in the dry season at the beginning of the year; its canopy is irregular about 20–30 m high, with emergent trees reaching 40 m ; the lower stratum is dominated by Araceae and Cyclanthaceae , and epiphytes are typically scarce in this phytocoenosis ( Ataroff & Sarmiento 2004 ). The natural history of
P. quihuai
remains virtually unknown; the only field notes on the type series indicate that all specimens were collected during nocturnal surveys and all of them were found on the ground, hidden in the leaf litter of the forest and shady coffee plantations. Although the specimens were collected at night (between 21:00–23:00 h), they were not observed actively foraging but were detected by leaf litter removal, which disturbed them, and caused them to move away from their shelters (D. Quihua, pers. comm.). From dissection, we noted that the specimen MHNLS 22711 has a relatively large oviductal egg, still without a calcified shell. The specimen MHNLS 22710 has a small piece of skin shedding inside its stomach. We suspect that is from itself, indicating the occurrence of shed skin eating in this species. Finally, the juvenile MHNLS 21644, the smallest of the series ( 15.4 mm SVL) shows a small and barely perceptible midventral umbilical scar, indicating that it had likely hatched recently.

Etymology. This species is named in honor of José Daniel Quihua Ramírez, a young self-taught naturalist and wildlife photographer, particularly passionate about the amphibians and reptiles of Venezuela . Daniel has been an outstanding collaborator of the first author during numerous field surveys and collected the type specimens of the new species.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 12. Panoramic view of the montane semideciduous forest (A) and its understory (B) in the eastern slope of the Andean Cordillera de Mérida, where
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
sp. nov.
inhabits. (C) Holotype (MHNLS 21643) and (D, E) paratypes (MHNLS 21644 and 22709, respectively) of
P. quihuai
sp. nov.
in life. Photos: F.J.M. Rojas-Runjaic (A, B) and D. Calcaño (C–E).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed (2000) reported on a specimen of
Pseudogonatodes
(MIZA 15-185 [Museo del Instituto de Zoología Agrícola, Maracay, Venezuela ]) from Las Cuevas, Uribante-Caparo hydroelectric complex, Táchira state , on the southern part of the eastern slope of the Cordillera de Mérida , Venezuela (sky-blue dot closest to the white cross in Fig. 1 ). At that time, the specimen could not be identified to the species level with certainty and the authors considered two possibilities: (i) that it represented an undescribed species, or (ii) a juvenile of
P. manessi
. Since then, specimen MIZA 15-185 had not been reexamined and no new specimens of
Pseudogonatodes
have been obtained from that locality. We reexamined the scale counts reported by Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed (2000) and some additional unpublished scale counts of the same specimen (see Table 1 ), and we preliminary conclude that: 1) The specimen MIZA 15-185 likely correspond to a species of the “3 rd Group” as it presents granular juxtaposed dorsal scales and high subdigital scale counts (7 LFIV and 9 LTIV); 2) MIZA 15-185 does not appear to be conspecific with
P. manessi
due to having a lower number of SAM (77 vs . 85–101), VTM (19 vs . 21), VMR-b (34 vs . 37–40), and VMR-c (29 vs . 31–35); in addition, we highlight that
P. manessi
is only known from the Venezuelan Cordillera de la Costa, whereas MIZA 15-185 comes from the southeastern portion of the Cordillera de Mérida (see Fig. 1 ); 3) MIZA 15-185 is not conspecific with
P. quihuai
since it has two postnasal scales ( vs . one), three posterior clefts on the mental scale ( vs . mental without clefts), and lower counts of SAM (77 vs . 85–91); and 4) MIZA 15-185 likely corresponds to a still undescribed species, but new data and additional specimens will be required in order to corroborate this hypothesis.

subSection.paragraph:
Improving the knowledge on the species diversity and systematics of the dwarf geckos in the genus
Pseudogonatodes
is challenging, not only due to the scarcity of museum specimens and concomitant lack of information on its morphological variation ( Parker 1935 ; Mechler 1968 ;
Montes-Correa et al . 2021
), but also by the paucity in external phenotypic characters useful to readily diagnose and delimit species ( Vanzolini 1967 ). As in other cases of small terrestrial vertebrates exhibiting low interspecific phenotypic variation and few external diagnostic morphological characters ( e.g. ,
Pristimantis
frogs), quantitative molecular phylogenetic studies will be required in order to test the validity of the current taxonomic hypotheses of species limits and to discover morphologically cryptic species in
Pseudogonatodes
, for which only a few specimens of three species have been sampled in molecular phylogenies ( i.e. ,
P. guianensis
,
P. lunulatus
, and
P. manessi , Gamble 2011b
;
Pyron et al . 2013
). We also stress the need to increase sampling efforts to reduce the Wallacean shortfall, which also significantly hampers the improvement of our understanding on the species distribution, systematics, and diversity of
Pseudogonatodes
. The discovery of
P. quihuai
, herein described, highlights the still underestimated diversity of this group of Neotropical dwarf geckos and underscores the need for further studies on its taxonomy and systematics.

Huey & Dixon (1970) hypothesized that high toe lamellae counts and an unexpanded third lamella on TIV , which characterizes the third group (currently including
P. furvus
,
P. gasconi
,
P. manessi
,
P. peruvianus
, and
P. quihuai
), may be an adaptation to scansorial foraging, while low counts and an expanded third lamella, as in their first (
P. guianensis
and
P. lunulatus
) and second (
P. barbouri
) groups, is related to terrestrial foraging. They argued that the few observations available at the time on the apparently scansorial habits of
P. furvus
and
P. peruvianus
, and terrestrial habits of
P. barbouri
, supported their hypothesis. Nevertheless, a few additional observations on the natural history of several
Pseudogonatodes species
published in subsequent studies, raised doubts about Huey & Dixon’s (1970) hypothesis. For example, the only known specimen of
P. gasconi
has high lamellae counts and unexpanded third lamella (third group) and, as predicted by Huey & Dixon (1970) , it appears to be scansorial, as it was found on a small tree in a dry varzea forest ( Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed 2000 ). However,
Rueda-Solano et al . (2014)
and
Montes-Correa et al . (2021)
reported on the finding of several specimens of
P. furvus
(a supposedly scansorial species) dwelling on the ground (in leaf litter, under fallen trunks and boulders), while
P. manessi
and
P. quihuai
, both also exhibiting the toe morphology of the third group ( i.e. , scansorial morphology sensu Huey & Dixon’s hypothesis), are typically found in the leaf litter of the forest floor ( Avila-Pires & Hoogmoed 2000 ; this study) and not on trees or rocky walls as predicted by Huey & Dixon (1970) . It is clear that further studies in field and laboratory are required to assess appropriately the putative functionality of the toe morphologies observed in
Pseudogonatodes
. Moreover, future molecular phylogenetic studies will shed light on the evolutionary relationships of the group, allowing determination of whether the three phenetic clusters actually represent natural groups and if their toe conditions are synapomorphic.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 2. Cranial osteological characters of
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
sp. nov.
and its congeners
P. barbouri
and
P. furvus
based on micro-CT scans.

th.emphasis: Shape of anterior margin of maxillary facial process

tr.td: rounded, merging gradually into dorsal margin
angular, with more acute transition into dorsal margin
rounded, merging gradually into dorsal margin
in medial contact along most of their length except anteriorly

th.emphasis: Shape of anteromedial margin between vomers

tr.td: with a V-shaped notch, forming the posterior part of the rectangular shaped premaxillary-vomerine fenestra
deeply notched, resulting in the formation of an elongated premaxillary-vomerine fenestra
vomers in contact anteromedially, leaving only a small slightly triangular opening to form a premaxillary-vomerine fenestra

th.emphasis: Basipterygoid process of basicranium contacts pterygoid

tr.td: completely fused, no sutures visible or completely separated
large, protruding anteriorly, not embedded in laminar bone
small, completely embedded in laminar bone
small, completely embedded in laminar bone

subSection.paragraph:
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
is an Andean species and its geographic distribution appears to be restricted to midelevations on the eastern slope of the Cordillera de Mérida . Although the ongoing loss of premontane and montane forest coverage in this region ( Ataroff & Sarmiento 2004 ; Castellanos-Montero & Rojas-Runjaic 2022 ) may pose a major threat to this silvicolous species, it seems to thrive in shaded coffee plantations and partially modified forests, and its range likely extends within the Ramal de Calderas National Park. However, taking into account that this lizard species is only known from a few specimens and from only two nearby localities, and that its ecology, population status, and other potential threats are virtually unknown, we suggest categorizing
P. quihuai
as “Data Deficient” (DD) according to the IUCN Red List (2022). We stress the need to increase our knowledge on the distribution and natural history of this species in order to properly assess its conservation status.

We thank Daniel Quihua, Daniel Calcaño, José Vieira, Dennys Mora, and the Rondón Martínez family for logistic support and field assistance during the herpetological surveys in which the type series of the new species was collected. Also, we thank Daniel Calcaño for sharing his photos of some specimens of the type series in life. To Juliano Romanzini (MCT-PUCRS) for the assistance during the acquisition of high resolution macrophotographs and focus stacking of the holotype . To Adolpho Agustin and the IPR-PUCRS, for the generation of high resolution computed microtomography scans and reconstruction of 3D digital models of the skeletons. To Fabrício Sarmento (MPEG) for the assistance during the revision of some specimens of
Pseudogonatodes
housed in the herpetology collection of the MPEG. Finally, we thank Teresa Avila-Pires and Andrés Montes-Correa for kindly sharing with us some unpublished scale counts of the specimen MIZA 15-185. FJMRR acknowledges the financial support from the Institutional Capacitation Program (PCI) of the MPEG – Brazilian Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovations (processes: 317738/2021-6, 300895/2022-4, and 300388/2023-3). ALCP was supported by grants from the Brazilian National Council of Technological and Scientific Development (CNPq) – Process: 302611/2018-5, PROTAX 441462/2020–0).

subSection.paragraph: APPENDIX 1. Museum specimens examined.

Pseudogonatodes gasconi

— BRAZIL : Pará: Oriximiná, Serra do Acarai (1.2830°, -58.7025°; 408 m asl), MPEG 27434–27436; Novo Progresso, BR-163, oeste de Castelo dos Sonhos (-8.4308°, -55.3456°; 274 m asl), MPEG 28475–28476, 28478–28480; 9 km S de Novo Progresso, 3, 5 km da BR-163, próximo ao aeroporto (-7.3783°, -56.7642°; 232 m asl), MPEG 28482, 28484.

Pseudogonatodes lunulatus

asl), MHNLS 17984.

APPENDIX 2. Morphometry of the type series of
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
sp. nov.
Catalog number of the holotype highlighted in bold. M: male; F: female;?: sex not determined. See acronyms in Material and Methods section. All measurements are in mm.

APPENDIX 3. Scale counts of the type series of
Pseudogonatodes quihuai
sp. nov.
Catalog number of the holotype highlighted in bold. M: male; F: female;?: sex not determined. Bilateral counts presented as right/left. Numbers in parenthesis in IL and SL correspond to the scales above eye and in LFI– V and LTI– V indicates divided lamellae. See acronyms in Material and Methods section.
